title: Case Study: Neuromyelitis Optica in a Middle-Aged Female
clinical_history: Mrs. Janet Alvarez is a 42-year-old accountant who presented to the outpatient neurology clinic with complaints of sudden bilateral lower limb weakness and severe central back pain that started seven days ago. Before her admission, she reported progressive blurred vision in her left eye, described as a dark patch, with associated pain during eye movement. Over the last three days, her ability to ambulate has deteriorated rapidly, necessitating the use of a wheelchair. She complains of a tight band-like sensation around her mid-thoracic region and reports urinary retention for the past 48 hours. Neurologic examination reveals profound lower limb weakness (Medical Research Council grade 1/5), marked spasticity, and hyperreflexia bilaterally. Sensory loss to pinprick and vibration is noted below the T6 dermatome. She denies any prior major neurological disorder other than intermittent migraines in her 20s. MRI of the spine demonstrates a longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis from T4 to T10. Serum testing is positive for anti-aquaporin-4 antibodies. A diagnosis of Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD) is made.

nprs.affected_area: central thoracic back (spinal cord band), bilateral lower limbs

aggrevating_factors: Movement or attempted transfers exacerbate thoracic back pain; exposure to heat worsens sensory symptoms. Left eye pain increases with ocular movement and bright light.
picture: [Illustrative diagram showing longitudinal myelitis from T4-T10, highlighting affected thoracic cord and optic nerve involvement in the left eye]
easing_factors: Rest in a supine position somewhat alleviates back pain; cold compress on left eye provides mild relief. High-dose IV methylprednisolone offers partial symptom reduction.
past_history: History of episodic migraines in her 20s with no neurological deficits. No prior autoimmune or demyelinating diseases reported.
medical_history: No known diabetes, hypertension, or cardiac disease. Family history unremarkable for autoimmune conditions.
medications: Currently on IV methylprednisolone (1g daily), acetaminophen for pain, and intermittent catheterization for urinary retention. No history of long-term medication use.
personal_history: Non-smoker, social alcohol use, married with one teenage son. Previously independent with activities of daily living and physically active, engaging in regular swimming.
imaging: MRI spine shows T4-T10 longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis; MRI brain unremarkable except for mild nonspecific white matter changes. Orbital MRI reveals left optic nerve enhancement.
